column4: How do I enable SSH as root on local LAN, but not from outside?
On my gateway, runs ClearOS, but I assume it's pretty much the same
sshd_conf "AllowUsers root@192.168.x.y"
but i'd always use PermitRootLogin forced-commands-only" and use su/sudo
root should have an unprilegded accoutn to login too
it's not ubuntu, but ClearOS
and? su/sudo works on every linux when installed
but there must be some way to disable su for my regular user?
just don't give him the root-password
there are lots of tutorials how to chroot users into $HOME using ssh or rbash
the other user is me, so i know the password..
that makes no sense
just don't use su then, why would you disable it
to make it more secure when opening ssh
how would that be more secure?
su needs the root-password. so if your account get hacked, the intruder has to know the root-pw too
chown root:wheel $(which su) && chmod 4550 $(which su)                     add those users to group "wheel", which should be able to use us
it still makes no sense, but ...
if that happens, you did something wrong
how should an attacker get the root-pw? by torturing you? then you have other problems, than your root-account
buy some more ram
